primary_factors: No accumulating snow or active precip expected Thu 2/12 (primary closure driver absent)
Temps/wind chill are cold but well above Michigan extreme-cold closure thresholds (no ≤ -20°F trigger)
Main risk window is pre-dawn dense/freezing fog + refreeze/black-ice on bridges/secondary roads (localized, not widespread)
No confirmed neighboring-district closure wave and no RPS Thu 2/12 closure/delay posting found as of Wed 2/11 scans
Power outage footprint appears very small and stable; no evidence of outage clusters forcing district-wide closure
decision_rationale:
All expert inputs align on the same base case: Thu 2/12 is a cold, quiet day with **0" new snow** and light winds, which in Michigan almost always means **school is open**. The only meaningful disruption pathway is *non-snow*: (1) lingering moisture from Wed’s light freezing rain signal refreezing into patchy black ice on secondary/rural roads and bridge decks, plus (2) possible dense/freezing fog during 6–8 AM. 

Conflicts were mostly about whether the forecast’s repeated “0-mile visibility” values are literal or an artifact. Follow-up meteorology supports treating “0 mi” as likely overdone/rounded and, if fog occurs, more **patchy** (river/low spots) than a countywide shutdown scenario. 

News intelligence did not find confirmed neighboring-district closures/delays on the main closings feed, and RPS did not post a Thu 2/12 weather decision in accessible site sections—both signals lean strongly away from a full closure. Infrastructure and power-grid inputs show no plow catch-up need and no major outage driver. 

Therefore: **low probability of a full snow day (closure)**, with the more realistic operational outcome being **OPEN**, and a smaller but real chance of a **2-hour delay** if dense fog (<1/4 mile) and slick secondary roads are confirmed on the ground right before bus dispatch.

collaboration.summary: Agents reached consensus after 1 round(s) with 3.0% spread. Average probability: 8%.
